conclusion: Determine how much object A rises and the spring constant k2 of spring C.
Initially, object A is at rest under the influence of gravity and spring B.
Force balance equation for object A at equilibrium is k1 x1 = mg.
Given m = 2 kg and g = 9.8 m/s^2.
Calculate k1 x1 = 2 x 9.8 = 19.6 N.
Initially, spring B is compressed by 9.8 cm.
When spring C is pulled to position b, tension force of spring B equals gravitational force of A.
Spring B is neither compressing nor extending object A under its weight, meaning it is in its natural length.
Let h be the height that object A rises from its initial position.
New force balance equation for object A is k1 x2 + mg = T.
Since tension in spring B equals weight of object A, k1 x2 = mg.
Calculate k1 x2 = 19.6 N.
Spring B extends by 9.8 cm when object A rises.
Total rise h of object A is h = x1 + x2 = 9.8 cm + 9.8 cm = 19.6 cm.
Horizontal displacement of right endpoint of spring C is 60 cm (0.6 m).
Force T exerted by spring C is T = k2 x 0.6.
Since T = 19.6 N, calculate k2 = 19.6 / 0.6 = 32.67 N/m.
The height that object A rises is 19.6 cm and the spring constant k2 of spring C is 32.67 N/m.
